page.title: 03FARMING IN LISMORE: CATTLE
page.content: { Cattle}fed on Lismore's fine grass do well in Oban sales.{Costs}are high in winter when cattle are fed on hay _ often bought in Stirlingshire, carried by lorry, with{MacBrayne freight}from Oban added. All feeding and fertiliser have this added cost, and MacBrayne must be paid for every cow and sheep going to or coming from market. In 1985 there are{13 bulls}on the island:{2 Aberdeen Angus, 5 Charolais, {6 Simmental.}Cows are{Shorthorn, {Simmental, Charolais, Frisian, {Hereford, Ayrshire}and{2 Jersey.}Seven farms have their own{milk,}though none is sold commercially. { Calves}are often born at 'the back end' and sold at the following main {October Sales.}Some are kept for two and a half years and sold as in-calf heifers.
